data.text: @mamavalveeta03 @thehill Can be, yes, yet the chances children  will be, are very very low. We known covid affects the elderly and people with multiple comorbidities. The chances of unvaccinated children getting seriously ill or even dying, are lower then a person who is 35 and double vaccinated.

@archiebell86 @thehill Again not an answer to my question..
How is my argument passively political and not understanding the science? When the data is very clear on who are at risk from covid and who are not. And it's not the kids, it's the elderly and people with multiple comorbidities like obesity...
@thehill Excellent.  Based on actual scientific evidence
@josh__gesell @Jerny16 @mic_moves @thehill It’s two years in. If they want to wear gloves still and sanitize their groceries let them. Just don’t touch my kids.

@gizmo359 @Jerny16 @mic_moves @thehill Everyone obviously needs the exact same medical advice regardless of age and health. That’s how all risk works for every illness. Because nearly a million ppl died…. These ppl are clowns.
@josh__gesell @Jerny16 @mic_moves @thehill If facts like that get out people would have to access their level of risk differently than an 80 year old. And they can’t be having that.

@JonathanWilk8 @thehill @GovRonDeSantis Not correct. Underlying health conditions typically means chronic medical conditions and a patient (or parents in this context) should know about it. How will a patient not know she has a heart disease or diabetes?

And people are free to be as docile as they want to be.

@FirkinToro @thehill Just go ahead and ignore the fact that Covid has reached a worldwide death toll of 9 million people and has long-term pulmonary and other effects. Your argument is passively political and not understanding science isn't an argument against it.
